Key Match Events: The Cubs started the second inning with four straight hits, including a two-RBI double by Pete Crow-Armstrong that put the team up a run.
Cody Bellinger capped off the frame with a two-run shot, giving the Cubs all the runs they’d score on the night.
Nate Pearson relieved Imanaga in the seventh and faced the minimum — giving up one hit and striking out two — in two scoreless frames.
Keegan Thompson needed five pitches to retire Crews, getting him to swing through a curveball to end the game.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Craig Counsell is known for his September runs — and he’s just one day away from his month.
The Cubs may use Jordan Wicks as a starter this weekend, but Javier Assad will pitch Saturday evening.
The Cubs also got some bullpen reinforcements when they picked up Shawn Armstrong, who was designated for assignment by the St. Louis Cardinals.
Post-Match Reflections: Counsell wasn’t going to push it with the young reliever Porter Hodge who has become so important to the team.
Counsell wasn’t going to use Jorge López Friday night, though.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Cubs are enjoying one of their hottest stretches of the season, having won four straight, 10 of 13 and are now 69-66.
The Cubs have lost a half-game in the wild-card standings — they’re five games back — due to the Atlanta Braves also rarely losing.
The team is playing as well as it has all season.
Others: Shawn Armstrong had a 2.84 ERA with a 24.5 percent strikeout rate and a 4.1 percent walk rate in 12 2/3 innings with the Cardinals after being traded there at the deadline.
Armstrong had a 1.38 ERA in 52 innings with the Rays in 2023.
Keegan Thompson has now faced 50 righties this season and has struck out 38 percent of them.
